Sure, here is a problem for a math student to solve:

A sample of a radioactive substance has an initial mass of 50 grams and a half-life of 10 days. Find the amount of the substance, to the nearest hundredth of a gram, that will be left after 30 days.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for exponential decay:

Final amount = Initial amount * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial amount is 50 grams, the half-life is 10 days, and the time elapsed is 30 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final amount = 50 * (1/2)^(30 / 10)

Final amount = 50 * (1/2)^3

Final amount = 50 * (1/8)

Final amount = 6.25 grams

So, after 30 days, there will be approximately 6.25 grams of the radioactive substance left, to the nearest hundredth of a gram.
